entry.title: Personalizing Success with SAP CX AI Toolkit: Unlocking Value with Custom Tool Builder
entry.content:
Introduction

Customer expectations are higher than ever. They want fast answers, personalized interactions, and consistent experiences across every touchpoint. Businesses know this, but delivering on it‚Äîat scale‚Äîhasn‚Äôt been easy. That‚Äôs where the SAP CX AI Toolkit comes in.

The SAP CX AI Toolkit offers ready-to-use AI features, and the Custom Tool Builder, the focus of this blog - adds the flexibility to tailor solutions to your business and industry needs. No generic responses, no one-size-fits-all. Just tools that give your teams exactly what they need‚Äîwhether it‚Äôs a sales rep preparing for a meeting, a service agent handling a customer request, or a product manager optimizing digital storefronts.

‚Ä¶and the Custom Tool Builder delivers business impact that is both commendable and strategically important‚Äî illustrated in the example use case flow below:

In this blog, we‚Äôll explore how the Custom Tool Builder creates real value in SAP Sales Cloud V1, SAP Service Cloud V2, and SAP Commerce Cloud. To make it practical, we‚Äôll walk through role-specific journeys and show how syntax, prompts, and outcomes connect directly to business results.

How It Works ‚Äì Syntax & Prompt Basics

Administrators can use the AI Tools Builder to design custom prompts grounded in SAP Cloud for Customer or SAP Sales & Service Cloud Version 2 data.
The goal: craft prompts that guide the AI to produce accurate, relevant, and business-aligned outputs.

Guiding Principles of Prompt Engineering

  1. Define the Context - Clarify the AI‚Äôs role (e.g., ‚Äúas a sales assistant, Service Agent, Commerce Manager..‚Äù) and the intended audience.
  2. Set the Desired Outcome - State the goal: What action, insight, or response do you expect?
  3. Provide Clear Guidance  - Be specific about context, outcome, tone, style, and format. Use examples to illustrate the expected output, Focus on what the AI should do (not what it shouldn‚Äôt), and add reference text or fields for grounding responses.
  4. Start Simple, Then Iterate - Begin with zero-shot prompting (no examples) to test the possible results, then move to one-shot (single example) or few-shot (multiple examples) for better accuracy. Also, break down complex tasks into smaller ones.

Example:

Example ‚Äì Syntax, Data Entities and Sources:

  • Standard Fields: Personalize responses with fields like {{ContactPerson.givenName}}.
  • Custom Fields: Extend prompts with fields unique to your business.
  • Wild Cards (*): Pull all available fields dynamically, including new ones when data changes.
  • Multiple Related Records (CRM): Use {{EntityName.List.EntityName}} to reference related data (e.g., all opportunities linked to an account).
  • Multiple Related Records (Commerce): Use similar references to ground prompts in Commerce Cloud data.

Key Takeaway: By defining context, guiding outputs clearly, and grounding prompts in SAP CX data (standard, custom, wildcards, or related records), administrators can unlock more personalized, accurate, and business-relevant AI responses.

More information can be found here: Create a Custom AI Tool And Prompt Engineering Tips for AI Tools Builder.

 

üìå‚ú®üõ†Ô∏è...Now, let‚Äôs make it practical with some few examples.

 

Sales Cloud V1 ‚Äì The Account 360 Every Rep & Managers Wants

 

  • The challenge: Preparing for meetings is time-consuming. Data is scattered across accounts, opportunities, notes, and service cases.
  • Who benefits: Sales Representatives / Sales Managers and other Sales Roles
  • The solution: A custom Account 360 tool that generates a clean, role-relevant summary.

Use case Description

This AI tool gives sales reps a 360-degree view of the customer account by pulling together account details, key opportunities, recent visits, service tickets, and notes. Instead of spending hours preparing, reps receive a ready-to-use summary in seconds, empowering them to walk into meetings fully prepared.

Prompt Example:

# CONTEXT # 

As a Sales Representative working for the Machinery Industry focused on steel production, I need a detailed summary of the account.

# OBJECTIVE #

This tool is designed to assist sales representatives in managing customer relationships efficiently, being better prepared for negotiations, and providing a true 360¬∞ customer view. The output should be based entirely on grounded SAP Sales Cloud V1 data.

# FURTHER INSTRUCTION FOR STYLE #

Write in a professional, neutral, and concise way. Use clear section headings (e.g., "Account Overview," "Opportunities," "Notes") and bullet points for readability. Add relevant emojis where they make the response more user-friendly.

# TASK #

Executive Summary:

Evaluate engagement based on relationships attached to the following entities: Account Detail, Activities, Leads, Opportunities, and Tickets:

     Activities: Most relevant ones only
     Leads: Most relevant ones only
     Opportunities: Highlight top 3 high-value ones
     Account Detail & Notes: Summarize recent interactions
     Service Cases: Mention open tickets with key details

Account details: {{CorporateAccount.*}}
Activities: {{CorporateAccount.List.Appointment}} {{CorporateAccount.List.PhoneCall}} {{CorporateAccount.List.Tasks}}
Leads: {{CorporateAccount.List.Lead}}
Opportunities: {{CorporateAccount.List.Opportunity}}
Service Tickets: {{CorporateAccount.List.ServiceRequest}}

-> Test it via playground and activate it.

Example of the configuration and outcome:

The Sales user can make it as favorite and use the new AI tool from the web application:

 

or through a web browser extension with in-context capability for SAP Sales Cloud V1. This means that when a user accesses a specific account, the input (specific account) automatically connects to that CX AI toolkit ‚Äîeliminating the need for the sales employee to manually filter or search for it. Example below:

and More about this feature here - User Interfaces - WebApp

 

Why this custom AI Tool matters: Instead of wasting time digging through multiple tabs, reps walk into ready and focused meetings. They know the customer‚Äôs latest concerns, hottest opportunities, and any risks. That confidence translates into higher win rates and stronger relationships.

 

Service Cloud V2 ‚Äì Handling Tickets with Empathy - Template for delay in resolving cases

  • The challenge: Customers expect empathy and clarity, even when things go wrong. But agents are often pressed for time and may default to generic replies & translation is needed to cope with different languages.
  • Who benefits: Service Agents
  • The solution: A tool that automatically crafts empathetic, customer-specific updates when tickets are delayed.

AI Use Case Description:

This AI tool helps service agents communicate ticket delays empathetically and consistently. By grounding prompts in SAP Service Cloud case data, it automatically generates customer-facing emails that explain revised due dates and reasons for delays, all while maintaining a professional, caring tone & content translated.

Prompt Example:

# OBJECTIVE #

Help agents send empathetic, transparent updates that maintain trust‚Äîeven in tricky situations. Also translate to English, Spanish, French, and Brazilian Portuguese, as these are the usual contact languages.

# FURTHER INSTRUCTION FOR STYLE #

Be professional yet warm. Keep it short and clear. Use emojis sparingly (‚Äå‚Äå for delays, ‚Äå‚Äå for commitments) to soften the message without losing professionalism.

# TASK #

Write an email that:

- Explains the revised due date.

- States the reason for the delay.

- Acknowledges the inconvenience while reaffirming commitment to resolution.

Case ID: {{Case.displayId}}
Case Contact: {{Case.contact.name}}
Case Type Description:  {{Case.caseTypeDescription}}
Original Due Date: {{Case.timePoints.completionDueOn}}

 

Test it via playground and activate it.

Example of the configuration and outcome:

 

The Service Agent user can make it as favorite and use the new AI tool from the web application  & & copy and paste the template/outcome easily:

or through CX AI toolkit embedded capability for SAP Service Cloud V2. This means that when a user accesses a specific case, the input (specific case) in the CX AI toolkit is embedded/connected to that Case ‚Äî eliminating the need for the sales employee to manually filter or search for it. Example below:

 

and More about this feature here - User Interfaces - Embedded Panel: SAP Sales and Service Cloud Version 2

 Why this custom AI Tool matters:  Instead of frustrated customers, you get reassured ones. Clear communication reduces escalations and improves satisfaction scores. And every agent‚Äîwhether new or experienced‚Äîmaintains the same high standard.

 

Commerce Cloud ‚Äì SEO That Scales

 

  • The challenge: Optimizing thousands of products for SEO is impossible to do manually.
  • Who benefits: E-Commerce Product Managers
  • The solution: A tool that generates optimized titles and descriptions, automatically grounded in product data.

 AI Use Case Description:
This AI tool enables product managers to scale SEO optimization effortlessly across the entire product catalog. By grounding in SAP Commerce Cloud product data, it generates meta titles and descriptions aligned with search engine best practices, increasing visibility, traffic, and conversions.

 Prompt Example:

The goal of this use case is to streamline the generation of SEO-optimized meta titles and descriptions for eCommerce products, enhancing visibility and click-through rates (CTRs) on search engine results pages (SERPs). This current tool builder utilizes the {{Product.*}} catalog and generates the meta title for {{Product.name}} and {{Product.defaultDescription}} ensuring that each meta title and description is unique, relevant, and adheres to SEO best practices. Also, take these instructions in consideration:

Meta Title Generation:

Length: Keep titles under 60 characters to avoid truncation in SERPs.

Structure: Place primary keywords at the beginning of the title.

Uniqueness: Ensure each title is distinct by incorporating product-specific details (e.g., size, color).

Call to Action: If space allows, include compelling phrases like ‚ÄúFree Shipping‚Äù or ‚ÄúShop Now‚Äù to enhance clickability.

Example Output:

‚ÄúRed Running Shoes ‚Äì Lightweight & Breathable | Free Shipping‚Äù

Meta Description Generation

Length: Aim for 155‚Äì160 characters to ensure full visibility.

Content: Summarize key product features, benefits, and USPs while incorporating primary keywords.

Call to Action: Include actionable phrases such as ‚ÄúDiscover More‚Äù or ‚ÄúBuy Today‚Äù to encourage clicks.

Uniqueness: Avoid duplication by tailoring descriptions to specific products.

Example Output:

‚ÄúShop our Red Running Shoes designed for comfort and speed. Lightweight, breathable fabric ensures a perfect fit. Buy today with free shipping!‚Äù

Example Outputs: - Title: ‚ÄúElegant Silk Evening Dress,  Backless | Shop Now‚Äù
- Description: ‚ÄúTurn heads in our silk evening dress with a stunning backless design. Perfect for formal events. Order now for free shipping! ‚Äù

 

Test it via playground and activate it.

Example of the configuration and outcome:

The E-Commerce Product Managers user can make it as favorite and use the new AI tool from the web application & copy and paste the outcome easily:

 

Why this AI tool matters: Instead of being buried on page three of Google, your products get found. More visibility means more traffic, which means more sales. And all without manually writing thousands of descriptions.

 

Wrapping Up

The Custom Tool Builder isn‚Äôt just another feature‚Äîit‚Äôs a way to unlock AI‚Äôs real potential in your business. By grounding prompts in SAP CX data, you ensure every output is:

  • Relevant: Specific to your business and your customers.
  • Consistent: On-brand and reliable across teams.
  • Efficient: Saving hours of manual work.
  • Impactful: Driving higher revenue, better customer satisfaction, and stronger loyalty.

In short, the Custom Tool Builder takes AI from being a generic assistant to becoming a trusted business partner for SAP Sales, Service, and Commerce Cloud.

We hope you have enjoyed the reading,
Thank you,

Luciano Monteiro,

CX Solution Value Advisory team.

entry.title: Re: Calculated Measure Temporary creation - SAC for plann...
entry.content:
@Deb_D 

You did not mention what will be the logic of the Measures you intend to create. From what you wrote it seems you want some restricted or filtered measures. You could use Restricted measures with Input controls to select the restriction parameters.

Scripting cannot create measures as such it can just help with UI task, setting filters on table etc. May be you can use them in combination but it will be helpful if you define the measure logic in detail or with an example.

Hope this helps !

Nikhil

entry.title: Re: How are SAP teams ensuring compliance with MCA Rule 1...
entry.content:
Hello @Udayaaa ,

To ensure full compliance with MCA Rule 11(g) in your SAP environment, it is crucial to establish a strong, tamper-resistant audit trail system that maintains all accounting transaction logs for a minimum of eight years, as required by the Ministry of Corporate Affairs.

Here are some important steps to help you reach this goal:

  • Enabling immutable audit logs at both application and database levels to ensure logs cannot be disabled, altered, or deleted by any user, including administrators.
  • Establish continuous daily monitoring and alerting to detect any tampering attempts or suspicious activities in real-time.
  • Aligning with KBA 3042258, which outlines statutory requirements for audit trail maintenance in SAP systems.
  • Utilising advanced security solutions such as ThreatSenseAI for automatic detection, restoration, and reporting of audit trails anomalies.
  • Implementing strict access controls and segregation of duties to prevent unauthorised manipulation of audit logs.
  • Keeping your system in an audit-ready state all year round to facilitate smooth statutory audits with no compliance gaps.

For detailed guidance, we recommend reviewing KBA 3042258 and the comprehensive framework provided by ToggleNow. at SAP Compliance for MCA Rule 11(g).

Implementing these measures will assist your SAP landscape in meeting and surpassing MCA Rule 11(g) requirements, delivering dependable, tamper-proof audit trails that uphold the integrity of your financial data throughout the mandated retention period.

Let me know if you need further support

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Train-The-Trainer SAP Analytics Cloud in Spanish by Marcela Revilla - Sponsored by UA
entry.content:
About this event

In this training course, we will introduce you to the latest version of the SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) - in particular the new ‚ÄúOptimized Story Experience‚Äù of the SAC Story Builder and the new SAC Modeler for data modelling.

In addition, you will learn about all the other possibilities and tools of the SAP Analytics Cloud - from data modeling to complete dashboards in the SAC Story Builder.

We will introduce you to the completely revised modular SAP UA SAC curriculum and use examples from teaching practice to show you how you can optimally arrange the components for your course and use them for the best possible knowledge transfer for your students.

In addition, you will gain your first practical experience in the SAP Analytics Cloud in practical exercises on the system, which you can then deepen with your demo access according to your needs at the end of the event.

Content:

  • Overview of the possibilities, tools and architecture of the SAC (curriculum module ‚ÄúPresentation slides for teachers‚Äù)
  • Components and usage options of the SAP UA curriculum for the SAC
  • Curriculum modules ‚ÄúSAC Navigation‚Äù and ‚ÄúSAC Story Builder introductory exercise‚Äù with practical exercises on the system
  • Curriculum module ‚ÄúSAC Story Builder Case Study‚Äù - with practical exercises on the system
  • Discussions and outlook

Participation is free of charge. Registration is only possible for lecturers at educational institutions with a valid academic email address.

Dates and times

üìÜ 16 & 17 October, Thursday & Friday, 8-12 h Mexico time 

Registration via this zoom link 

The online training takes place with a minimum of 7 participants.

This training has been sponsored by SAP UA

entry.title: Re: SAP S4/HANA Cloud Public, G/L account hierarchy 1799...
entry.content:
Hello @rekafulop 

Thank you for your update regarding the creation of FSV 1799 and the balance validation issues, and my apologies for the late reply

To address the problem, please ensure the following.

  • Please double-check that the balance validation rules are properly set up and active for FSV 1799 in the Manage Balance Validation Rules and Groups app. This helps ensure everything runs smoothly.
  • Make sure all rule details, like ledger, company code, account ranges, and currency, match your settings and postings to keep everything in sync.
  • Please double-check that the posting data for the relevant entities and periods are available and complete. Missing data might lead to validation errors, so it's good to ensure everything is in place.
  • Review the consistency of the review period and ledger with the FSV configuration.
  • If applicable, take a moment to check for any specific FSV settings, like row grouping, that could influence how balance validation is processed. This little step can help ensure everything runs smoothly!

For additional help, feel free to check out these helpful SAP resources.

  • View Balance Validation Results app documentation, which helps analyse validation results and failure reasons.
  • Manage Balance Validation Rules and Groups app for configuring and activating rules.

If problems persist, please provide the specific error messages, and we'll help with further diagnosis.

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: MTD and Advanced Compliance Reporting
entry.content:
Hi @GLENT 

Thank you for your message. Let me walk you through.

Please note, HMRC does provide a sandbox/test environment for Making Tax Digital VAT submissions that authorized software providers can use to test integrations. You need to register a test user on the HMRC Developer Hub to get your test credentials. Using these will enable you simulate the desired VAT obligation requests and submissions via the sandbox. This allows you to validate processes before going live.


Once a return period is submitted to HMRC, it is generally locked for further changes. If transactions are posted late HMRC expects these to be reflected in the next open return period, not the locked prior one. So effectively, ‚Äòbackpostings‚Äô should flow into the next available return period to maintain compliance and audit trail integrity.


Posting Postponed VAT Accounting without manual adjustments on the VAT return boxes is challenging as VAT returns usually require specific box adjustments that SAP standard processes often don‚Äôt automate fully. While manual box adjustments are common, please note that they lack detailed audit trails in SAP S/4HANA. Some businesses deploy custom developments or enhanced reporting to strengthen audit capabilities around VAT box postings and adjustments.

I hope this provides some useful insights. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: CORS for SAP PO REST Sender Adapter
entry.content:
@RodolfoTorrado 


"Allow public access" - Check the box
"Allow cross site requests" - Select "Allow only specific clients"
"CORS enabled URIs)" - Add whatever is shown in "from origin" in your error message, including the port number.

Example https://xyz-mycompany.com:8080, https://mycompany.com etc. (comma separated list)

When configuring CORS policies, you must ensure that the allowed origins (domain) include the correct port number if it deviates from the default ports (80 for HTTP and 443 for HTTPS)

Hope this helps

entry.title: Re: Company DB is not consistent; see log [Message 131-21...
entry.content:
Hello @Joo_Leo 

Thank you for your question

When updating the database from version 2111 to 2505, an error occurs: Company DB is not consistent. This is indicated in log Message 131-219, which indicates a database inconsistency caused by an incomplete or failed upgrade.

Direct Solution:

  • Check the upgrade log files for specific errors.
  • Verify the database schema version matches the application version.
  • If inconsistency persists, restore the database from a backup before the upgrade and rerun the update.
  • Contact SAP support if the issue persists to prevent data loss.

References for troubleshooting and resolution:

  1. The SAP Community guide on Company DB is not consistent with the error.
  2. SAP Business One Administrator's Guide for upgrade procedures and error handling.

This approach helps you address the root cause effectively and with confidence.

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Documentation for DDIC tables of the DRC module
entry.content:
Hi @martin_lehmann4 

Thank you for your question. 

Regarding your requirement to display VAT return transactions from both DRC and FI-GL-GL-F content in a single custom query, here are a few details and suggestions.

The main DRC table you identified is SRF_REP_RUN_DATA, which holds data for statutory reporting.

Unfortunately, SAP documentation on linking SRF_REP_RUN_DATA to individual transactions is limited to a large extent.

Please note that, typically, SRF_REP_RUN_DATA stores aggregated or processed reporting data rather than raw transactional line items.

For FI-GL-GL-F data, tables like FOTTDCLNOT and FOTDECLSTA hold declaration and status information as you mentioned.

Moving forward, i suggest you explore SAP legal reporting framework or statutory reporting frameworks where these data sources may be linked through reporting layers or views.

It might also be of help to review SAP program logs or report generation logic that populates SRF_REP_RUN_DATA for clues on field mappings.

You may consider engaging SAP support or consulting legal reporting experts for detailed guidance on DRC table usage and extensions.

Looking into your custom query, joining DRC aggregated data with detailed FI transactional tables may require custom logic or mapping tables because it is not a straightforward link.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Integration suite unsubscription failed
entry.content:
Hello @FranckMebal 

Thank you for reaching out. The "Unsubscription Failed" error you encountered in your SAP Integration Suite trial account typically occurs due to temporary service disruptions or restrictions within the trial environment.

Please try the following steps:

  • Wait a few moments and try again to unsubscribe.
  • Clear your browser's cache and cookies or try using a different browser.
  • Make sure you have the correct permissions to manage subscriptions during your trial account.

For more detailed guidance, please refer to the SAP Integration Suite documentation on the SAP Help Portal and the SAP Community topic on Integration Suite:

  • SAP Help Portal: https://help.sap.com/viewer/product/ SAP_INTEGRATION_SUITE
  • SAP Community: https://community.sap.com/topics/integration-suite

Please do not hesitate to contact me if you require any further assistance.

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Navigating the Future: Understanding Upcoming Changes to SAP Universal ID
entry.content:
@Akhat_12 could you please clarify how the future authentication will work in detail? 

In your post you wrote: 

Instead, authentication will now require an email address and a dedicated password.

But today the SAP UID is an e-mail address with a password. So I do not see where this would be any change. Furthermore, on the following page https://www.sap.com/account/universal-id.html?sap-outbound-id=6BF4E20C2BE9A25208F18487FE01DED3C49BD508&smc_campaign_id=0000050180&source=email-smc it is written that authentication would be done with a dedicated user identity which is by my understanding an S-, P- or C-User, contradicting your statement. 

I would also like to get a clarification how the authentication to the SAP UID account manager will work in future. Will this also be identity (S-User) based, which would finally allow us to activate state of the art authentication methods like two factor authentication or is this still using the UID e-mail and password combo which we highlighted as a security risk months ago without any action from SAP?

entry.title: Re: Datasphere, SAP BPT Core Account
entry.content:
Hello @FelipeCadena @afonso_figueiredo 

Thank you for your question and I hope you both can still make use of this answer.

To change your subaccount entry in the SAP BTP Core Account section in Datasphere:

Go to the System / Administration area in Datasphere. Then navigate to the Data Source Configuration tab where you see the SAP BTP Core Account details. Unfortunately, the Email and Subaccount fields once entered are often not directly editable from this screen.

To correct a mistaken subaccount, there are a few steps you should consider:

First, you may need to remove or unregister the current SAP BTP Core Account connection.

Then re-register or add a new SAP BTP Core Account with the correct subaccount information.

Alternatively, you can check if there is a Change Cloud Platform User or similar button available to update your SAP BTP connection.

Please note, if the UI does not support direct change, delete and recreate the connection with your correct subaccount.

Please also verify in the SAP BTP Cockpit that you are using the intended subaccount and region matching what you configure in Datasphere.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris
